Dear Shawn M Knodel:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Eligibility requirements
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504
Section
Description
1

• (3) An independent living home, staffed and operated by
the child placing agency, must be clean, safe, and
appropriate to the needs of the youth it serves.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Numerous youths have sanitation concerns regarding the home.
The water being used is contaminated and has a black like
substance coming out prior to water coming out. There are also
water pressure issues in which the pressure is low, or the water
completely stops. There are issues with the heating and air
conditioning.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Youth A was interviewed in person on 1/6/2025 at Corcoran
House, the Independent Living (IL) home where she is living and
reported concerns with the water home. She stated, there are
youths in the home who don’t shower because the water has
caused them to have yeast infections and rashes, her skin has
broken out from the water, the water makes the sinks, tubs, and
showers rusty, and the water pressure and temperature are
inconsistent. She reported there is a water filter in the kitchen the
youths can use for drinking water; however, there are no filters in
the bathrooms. She has complained about the water to the
Program Manager and other staff of the home and was told filters
were being installed on all of the shower heads, but that has not
happened. Youth A stated she has video footage of black water
coming from a tub faucet and water barely coming out of a shower
head.
Youth A reported having concerns with bugs in the home in the
past, but there are currently no bugs in the home. She stated
there were a couple weeks when there were stink bugs, lady
bugs, and spiders in the home as well as frogs in the basement.
She does not know if the home was treated for bugs/frogs, but
they are no longer a concern.
Youth A reported concerns with the temperature throughout the
bedrooms in the home not being consistent. She stated some
youths’ rooms are too cold, but her room is too hot, so she sleeps
with a fan propped in her open window.
Youth B was interviewed in person on 1/6/2025 at Corcoran
House, the Independent Living (IL) home where she is living and
reported concerns with the water. She stated she has sensitive
skin due to having psoriasis and has gone to the hospital for
2

painful skin irritations after showering. Staff at the hospital
recommended she obtain a free home water test from Home
Depot, which she did. The test showed the “hardness was off”
which was exacerbating her psoriasis. She reported she had been
getting a lot of dry spots on her body, mostly on her legs, but it
has improved. She stated she has previously lived in a home with
hard water, but it wasn’t like the water in Corcoran House. She
stated the staff say there is a water softener and that all of the
showers have filters, but Youth B doesn’t believe that to be true.
Youth B’s only concern with bugs in the home was a lot of gnats
that she hasn’t seen since a “certain resident” moved out of the
home.
Youth B reported her bedroom has wide windows, so it tends to
get cold in her room. She stated a heavy curtain over her window
would help the windows as they need better insulation.
Youth C was interviewed in person on 1/6/2025 at Corcoran
House, the Independent Living (IL) home where she is living and
reported having concerns with the water. She stated the water can
be hot one day then cold the next or barely coming out of the
faucet. She also stated; black stuff has come out of the shower
heads, some of the youths get rashes from the water, and she
developed a rash when she first moved into the home, but she
has eczema and has cream to use for her skin condition.
Youth C reported not having concerns with bugs in the home or
the temperature of her bedroom.
Youth C reported the faucet in her bathroom sink is loose and
moves.
Youth D was briefly interviewed in person on 1/6/2025 at
Corcoran House, the Independent Living (IL) home where she is
living after she stepped out of her bedroom and asked if the visit
was about the water. She reported the water pressure and
temperature are not consistent and the water is rusty, at times.
ILP Caseworker was interviewed in person on 1/6/2025 at
Corcoran House and reported some of the youths in the home
have complained the water dries out their skin. She stated the
home has well water that is tested every other week and she
believes there is a water filter and water softener installed. She
stated she doesn’t think there are filters on showers.
3

ILP Caseworker did not have concerns with bugs in the home and
was not aware of any youths having these concerns.
ILP Caseworker stated one youth switched rooms because she
stated her room was cold and wanted a warmer room, but she
was unaware of any other concerns with bedroom temperature.
ILP Caseworker was not told about Youth C’s sink faucet.
Program Manager was interviewed by phone on 1/9/2025 and
reported the home has well water that is treated and tested once a
month. She stated she is not used to hard water and feels that
most of the youths in the home aren’t either. When a faucet is first
turned on in the home there might be a strong iron smell. She
reported there is a water softener in the home and there were
filters on all of the shower heads in the past, but they currently
aren’t installed. She added she can look into getting filters
installed on the shower heads. Program Manager reported they
talked about the water concerns during the last house meeting.
She stated maintenance has come out to the home multiple times
for the water pressure concerns, but she can have them look at it
again.
Program Manager stated the home is in the country, so bugs do
appear, but they have not had any infestations. She reported the
home in treated for insects monthly during summer.
Program Manager reported there was one bedroom in the home
that had cool air instead of warm blowing out of the vent, so the
youth in that room was moved to a different room and
maintenance was notified. She stated there is difficulty regulating
the temperature in the home because some of the youths like to
keep their bedroom windows open.
Director of Maintenance was interviewed by phone on 1/16/2025
and reported the home has a well and testing is performed
quarterly. The home’s primary water filter is changed every 6
weeks. He reported the home’s water softener is maintained by an
outside company who provides the maintenance and filters, and
the water softener has a display which indicates that it is
functioning properly. He stated a water test was completed
11/14/2024 then another approximately a week ago due to the
concern reported by the youths. He stated the test came back with
no concerns for the water. He called the testing company and
described the concerns the youths were reporting with the water
and was told it sounded as if there might be a mold issue which
4

would have to be tested by a different company. He called a
company who came out and tested for mold. He reported trace
amounts of mold were found in the water and the testing company
stated the mold was likely coming from stagnant water
somewhere in the water system. Director of Maintenance called
the Genesee Health Department and was told to contact a
professional well driller for assistance. A professional well driller
went to the home yesterday, 1/15/2025 and found the home’s
expansion tank had failed and was filled with stagnant water which
was likely being drawn into the homes water lines. He stated the
well driller is returning to the home, on 1/17/2025 to replace the
expansion tank and gauges.
Director of Maintenance reported the only issue with that home is
box elder bugs appearing in the home as there is a box elder tree
on the property. He stated the home has contracted services for
treatment of insects, including box elder bugs, on a monthly basis.
Director of Maintenance reported the bedrooms at the back of the
home are connected to the furnace and the bedrooms upstairs are
connected to the boiler system, so the temperature amongst the
bedrooms might vary and it’s difficult to balance the temperature
so each room is the same temperature. He reported they address
any temperature concerns through their work order system
whenever they come up.
Director of Maintenance reported he was not aware of the loose
bathroom sink faucet but will have someone go out tomorrow to
look at it.
VIDEO REVIEW
• 1/6/2025 – Reviewed video on Youth A’s phone of water
trickling out of the shower head when turned on.
• 1/6/2025 – Reviewed video on Youth A’s phone of what
appeared to be dark gray water coming out of a tub faucet.
TOUR OBSERVATION
A tour of Corcoran House was completed 1/6/2025. The following
was observed:
• Iron stains in the bathroom sinks, toilets, and tubs.
• The bathroom next to Youth C’s bedroom had a loose sink
faucet.
• Clear water when a bathtub faucet was turned on.
• Bathroom faucet water smells slightly sulfurous.
• No bugs were present.
5

• The temperature in the home was comfortable.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• 12/19/2024 home drinking water test results photos
provided by Youth B showing the following
• Elements within “ok” range
1. Copper
2. Nitrate
3. Chlorine
• Elements outside of the “ok” range
1. overall hardness 250ppm
2. alkalinity 180
3. pH - 9
4. Iron – 1ppm
• CDC.GOV – “Guidelines for Testing Well Water” stating:
1. pH/alkalinity levels above 8.5 can affect the
water pipes as well as how the water looks
and tastes but does not pose a health risk.
2. Iron levels above .3mg/L, can result in rusty
color, sediment, metallic taste, and
reddish/orange staining, but does not pose a
health risk.
3. Total dissolved solids over 500 mg/L
increases water hardness, deposits, colored
water, staining, and salty taste, but does not
pose a health risk.
4. Aesthetic, cosmetic, and technical effects of
elements of well water are undesirable tastes
and odors, effects which do not damage the
body but are undesirable, and damage to
water equipment.
5. Water should be tested for Coliform and
E. coli which can pose health risks.
• 1/8/2025 Genesee County Drain Commissioners’ water
sample results indicating the water is negative for Coliform
and E.coli.
• 1/14/2025 Paragon laboratories water sample results
indicating a yeast and mold count of 13CFU/ml.
• Epa.gov – United States Environmental Protection Agency
“A Brief Guide to Mold, Moisture and Your Home,” which
states that no EPA or other federal limits have been set for
mold or mold spores.
6

• 1/17/2025 Invoice from Vanover’s Well Repair for
installation of a 50-gallon tank, pressure switch and gauge,
and miscellaneous fittings.
• 12/2/24 Rose Pest Solution invoice.
Analysis The agency is found in violation as, at the time of the allegation
and investigation, mold was present in the water.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
